name: The Eagle
abilities: Soaring Flight: Can reach heights beyond other birds
Sun-Gazing: Legendary ability to look directly at the sun
Keen Vision: Perceives prey from vast distances
Renewal: Legendary self-renewal through fire and water
Parental Testing: Tests offspring by sun exposure

christian.overview: The eagle represents spiritual transcendence, divine vision, and renewal in Christian symbolism. Associated with John's Gospel and the contemplative life, the eagle soars to heights representing the soul's aspiration toward God.

biblicalParallels.description: The eagle face of the living creatures represents divine omniscience and the Spirit's descent from heavenly heights.
"They who wait upon the LORD shall renew their strength; they shall mount up with wings as eagles" - the foundational text for Christian eagle symbolism.
God compared to an eagle stirring up the nest, bearing Israel on his wings - a powerful image of divine nurture and protection.
"Your youth is renewed like the eagle's" - connected to legends of eagle rejuvenation and applied to baptismal renewal.
The woman given "two wings of a great eagle" to escape the dragon represents the Church protected by divine power.

patristicInterpretation.summary: Church Fathers emphasized the eagle's ability to gaze at the sun without blinking as a symbol of contemplating divine glory, and its legendary renewal as an image of baptismal regeneration.

sources.author: Augustine of Hippo
sources.interpretation: The eagle's renewal represents the Christian's renovation through grace: as the eagle was thought to renew its feathers by flying near the sun, so the soul is renewed by drawing near to Christ, the Sun of Righteousness.

sources.author: Gregory the Great
sources.interpretation: The eagle's high flight represents contemplative prayer that rises above earthly concerns to gaze upon eternal realities.

sources.author: Irenaeus of Lyon
sources.interpretation: Assigned the eagle to John's Gospel because it begins "In the beginning was the Word" - taking the highest view, gazing directly at Christ's divinity.

medievalSymbolism.bestiaryMeaning: Bestiaries taught that the eagle tests its young by making them gaze at the sun, raising those who can do so and rejecting those who cannot - interpreted as God testing believers' faith through trial.
medievalSymbolism.evangelistSymbol: The eagle represents John the Evangelist (in the standard Western scheme), whose Gospel soars to the highest theological heights, beginning with the Logos.
medievalSymbolism.artisticRepresentation: Eagle lecterns in churches symbolize the Gospel spreading on wings of inspiration; the eagle supports the Word because John's Gospel is read from the highest vantage.
medievalSymbolism.renewalLegend: Medieval tradition held that aged eagles flew into the sun's fire, singed their old feathers, then plunged into water to emerge renewed - an elaborate baptismal allegory.

christian.typologicalReading: The eagle's flight toward the sun and renewal through fire and water prefigures the Christian journey: ascending through prayer, purified by divine fire, renewed through baptismal waters, and finally rising to gaze upon the Light of God.
christian.liturgicalPresence: Eagle symbols pervade church architecture (lecterns, capitals, windows), representing the Gospel's ability to soar above earthly confusion and bring divine perspective.
christian.spiritualAscent: The eagle's flight became a central metaphor for mystical theology: the soul ascending through contemplative stages to direct vision of God (as the eagle gazes unflinching at the sun).
